When to take a COVID-19 test  1. If you receive a positive result on a home COVID-19 test  After receiving a positive result on a home COVID-19 test, you must complete a PCR or authorized antigen test so that you can be considered a confirmed patient by the Health System and then considered to be recovering.    Please note: Positive results on a home COVID-19 test cannot be used to define a person as verified and then as recovering, since it is not registered within the Heath System.    2. If you are a confirmed COVID-19 case  The duration of isolation for verified COVID-19 patients is 7 days. You can exit the isolation in 5 days if you receive two negative test results in a home antigen test taken on day 4 eve and on day 5 eve (positive test day being first day), and only if there are no symptoms 48 hours prior, and you received a HMO recovery certificate.    3. Before visiting a health and welfare facilities  When visiting health and welfare facility (for example, assisted living facility or a nursing home) you must present a negative result on an authorized antigen test you did within 24 hours of entering the place, or proof of a negative result on a home antigen test you performed within 24 hours of entering the facility (children under age 3 do not require a pre-visit test).    4. 'Magen Education' program:  Until 30.5.2022, PCR test are performed once a week for students in the educational institutions participating the âMagen Educationâ program.    When to take a COVID-19 test  In addition to cases where a test should be done, there are cases when it is recommended to take a test, especially for those aged 60 and older and for those in at-risk groups, to find out if you were infected and to receive medical treatment in time.    These are the cases where it is recommended to take a COVID-19 test:  1. 72 hours after exposure to a confirmed COVID-19 case  If you were exposed to a confirmed COVID-19 patient, it is recommended to take a home test 72 hours after the exposure. In case the result is positive â you must take a PCR test or an authorized antigen test to be considered as confirmed with COVID-19 and later as a recovering case in the Health System.    2. If there are symptoms consistent with COVID-19  If you have fever, cough, or difficulty breathing â it is recommended to take a home COVID-19 test. In case the result is positive â you must take a PCR test or an authorized antigen test to be considered as confirmed and later as recovering case in the Health System.    3. After receiving a borderline-positive PCR test result  It is recommended to take another PCR test or an authorized antigen test within 24 to 72 hours after the first test. If the result is positive â you will be considered as confirmed with COVID-19 and later as a recovering case.
